;;马琳·勒庞
;

;法国极右翼领导人马琳·勒庞对以色列的支持哈马斯袭击事件被视为长期努力的一部分，目的是让她的全国集会党在 2027 年竞选总统之前摆脱有毒的反犹太主义过去。

;

;全国集会，这是现在是;最大的反对党;法国议会正在;投票< /a>; 在埃马纽埃尔·马克龙 (Emmanuel Macron) 的中间派参加明年的欧洲选举之前，自 10 月 7 日哈马斯袭击以及随后对加沙的轰炸以来，坚定支持以色列自卫的权利。

;

;在议会的一次演讲中谴责以色列的自卫权。她称这是“以色列领土上的大屠杀”，并攻击让-吕克·梅朗雄领导的左翼无党派政党不将哈马斯列为恐怖组织的“令人无法容忍”的立场，勒庞得到了来自传统右翼和中间派议员的掌声。

;

;当她准备在 2027 年第四次竞选总统时，她的反移民政党承诺保护法国犹太人免受其所谓的最大危险：伊斯兰主义的侵害。该党主席乔丹·巴尔德拉 (Jordan Bardella) 向法国电台表示：“对于许多法国犹太人来说，全国集会是抵御伊斯兰意识形态的盾牌。”

;

;法国对中东冲突高度敏感，社区中的犹太人大约有五十万犹太人——以色列或美国以外最大的犹太人——超过;自 10 月以来，警方记录了 800 起反犹太主义事件;。法国还拥有欧洲最大的穆斯林社区。;

;玛丽娜·勒庞对以色列的支持被一些评论家视为某种政治机会主义。她长期以来一直寻求使她的政党“正常化”，并使其摆脱过去的反犹太主义，这被视为对该党新政治野心的阻碍。 2015 年，勒庞驱逐了她的父亲、该党创始人让-马里·勒庞，因为他重申了贬低大屠杀的言论，为此他;多项定罪;。她后来将党名从国民阵线改为国民集会。

;

;勒庞的几名议员十月份参加了由犹太团体领导的支持以色列的巴黎游行，这是一个极具象征意义的举动。与往年相比，这是一个根本性的变化。 2018 年，勒庞试图参加纪念 ;Mireille Knoll;，一名犹太养老金领取者，在一次反犹太主义谋杀中被杀，但在一些;“法西斯分子出局”;。

;

;尽管勒庞做到了虽然没有亲自参加以色列游行，但身为议会法以友好团体成员的几位全国集会政客却悄悄参加了。法国犹太组织保护伞组织 Crif 的负责人约纳森·阿尔菲 (Yonathan Arfi) 告诉 ;《世界报》; 他将在 2027 年总统选举中与全国集会作战，显然没有邀请他们或与他们交流以某种方式使他们合法化，但街道向所有人开放。

;

;犹太团体继续对反移民的极右翼政党表示担忧，包括对可能禁止犹太人入境等政策问题的担忧。仪式屠宰，包括犹太食品，以及犹太人是否应该被允许在公共场合穿着基帕。

;

;法国恐怖袭击的岁月，来自图卢兹的面板攻击者 ;穆罕默德·梅拉 (Mohammed Merah); 2012 年袭击一所犹太学校到 2015 年巴黎袭击，其中包括一家犹太超市，导致勒庞的政党越来越关注伊斯兰主义。

;
;

;;相关：;;“很多痛苦”：欧洲犹太人担心哈马斯袭击后反犹太主义抬头;;

;“她父亲的过去变得越来越遥远，”加缪说。 “出生于 1920 年代末的让-马里·勒庞 (Jean-Marie Le Pen) 现年 95 岁。如今，18 岁至 24 岁的选民（全国集会得分最高的年龄段）从未了解过让-马里·勒庞时代。< /p>;

;“玛丽娜·勒庞的问题是她永远无法摆脱过去——它是由历史学家和政治学家写下的。国民阵线一开始是一个极右政党，其成员中有新法西斯主义者、新纳粹分子、否定主义者、反犹太主义者。这是她永远无法抹去的。但与英国民族党这样极端、不知道如何成为政党的政党相比，勒庞的民族集会长期以来一直是一个不再处于边缘的政党。我们今天看到的是勒庞和她的随行人员的战术政治意识。”

;
;

;;相关：;;让-吕克·梅朗雄对法国左派来说是一场灾难——他对以色列袭击事件的反应证明了这一点 |斯坦福大学教授、勒庞政党专家亚历山大·赫斯特;

;
;

;塞西尔·阿尔杜伊 (Cécile Alduy) 表示：“国民阵线有着悠久的反犹太主义历史：其创始人之一是武装党卫军[成员]和让·马里·勒庞因否认或淡化大屠杀或反犹太主义诽谤而多次被定罪。让-马里·勒庞也对 90 年代的巴勒斯坦人民表示同情，并反对美国在中东政治上的任何结盟。

;

;“但该党始终支持以色列的存在 — —年轻的让-马里·勒庞 (Jean-Marie Le Pen) 是 1956 年苏伊士运河行动的崇拜者，2001 年 9 月 11 日之后，极右翼开始将以色列视为阿拉伯世界中西方在一场文明战争中的飞地。”;

;“全国集会已开始针对以色列移民中根深蒂固的反犹太主义。穆斯林传统，并试图通过假装保护犹太社区免受穆斯林的伤害来在这方面购买新的童贞，”她说。

;

;阿尔杜伊说：“马琳·勒庞反对停火，似乎并不支持人道主义走廊，她的[国会议员]已致电巴勒斯坦受害者;“附带损害”;是彻底消灭哈马斯所必需的。这清楚地表明，希望将全国集会对以色列的绝对支持与伊斯兰主义者和极左翼分子的模糊立场进行对比。这当然符合全国集会的正常化叙事。”

;;基辅市中心北约徽章前的乌克兰和欧盟旗帜
;

;乌克兰将有副首相表示，在两年内完成了加入欧盟所需的改革，并坚称该国不希望在即将举行的领导人峰会上进行同情票来决定欧盟的扩大。

;

;周三发表的一份评论预计将揭示欧盟委员会关于是否应与那些在入盟改革方面最先进的国家展开谈判的立场。

;

;“我们不希望因为战争而有任何折扣，”奥尔加·斯特凡尼西娜 (Olga Stefanishyna) 表示，她对做出有利于国家的决定充满信心。

;

;“我们正在讨论的两年时间表只是为了确保我们在法律上为入盟做好准备，指令的标准、规则和义务，”她说。

;

;“从总统到每位地方长官，每个人都团结在一起，为了两个目标：赢得战争并确保胜利后的第二天我们还没有开始加入欧盟的进程，但我们正在结束它。”具体负责乌克兰的欧洲和欧洲-大西洋一体化事务的 Stefanishyna 说道。

;

;布鲁塞尔广泛认识到，持续的错误的曙光使政客们很难保持欧盟梦想，因为他们自己的选民面临着俄罗斯在东欧扩大影响力的风险。

;

;“在乌克兰申请加入欧盟之前，曾是欧盟内部的禁忌话题。没有得到人们的大力支持。巴尔干地区有很多复杂的情况。乌克兰重新启动了讨论，”斯特凡尼西纳 (Stefanisyna) 描述了战争对欧盟东扩态度转变的影响。

;

;正是由于东扩的紧迫性，德国上周建议将乌克兰与欧盟一体化。;其他国家可能会加速进入欧盟; 早在加入之前就已给予会员福利，并提供一些单一市场准入和领导人峰会观察员地位。

;

;这些提案受到了北马其顿的欢迎，该国已经等待加入会员国近 20 年了，并且抱怨说，如果欧盟不断改变目标，选民就很难保持梦想。

;

;其外交部长布贾尔·奥斯马尼 (Bujar Osmani) 表示，它经历了入盟过程中的所有“缺陷”，并指出欧盟“关注正式成员身份本身”的问题。他补充说，德国的提案可以解决这个问题。

;

;乌克兰是;去年夏天加入了正式候选人名单;，并建议优先考虑以司法治理、反腐败立法和反寡头化为中心的七组改革其中。

;

;Stefanishyna 还谈到了对乌克兰农业贸易规模的国家可能对欧盟单一市场产生扭曲影响的担忧。

;

;在 ;半年审查;，欧盟邻国和扩大事务专员奥利弗·瓦勒伊 (Olivér Várhelyi) 表示，已经完成了其中两项令欧盟满意的步骤，在另一组方面取得了良好进展，在其余四个主题上也取得了“一些进展”。

;

;全年回顾将于周三发布。

;

;Stefanishyna 表示，自 6 月以来，该国在改革方面取得了巨大进展，并已准备好应对反对快速入盟的论点，包括扭曲劳动力和农业市场。

;

; >;

;关于自由流动，她指出，战后逃往欧盟的估计有 900 万乌克兰人都享有工作权利，而与欧盟达成的临时贸易自由化协议使其能够免关税进入欧盟。一系列农产品的单一市场。

;;1964 年约翰·列侬、乔治·哈里森、林戈·斯塔尔和保罗·麦卡特尼在利物浦
;

;电影-制作人彼得杰克逊暗示披头士乐队的“最后”歌曲《Now and Then》发行后可能会推出更多音乐，称这个想法“可以想象”。

;

;Now and Then 是根据录音制作的这是约翰·列侬在 1980 年被谋杀前不久制作的，使用了杰克逊在他的纪录片《回归》中使用的相同人工智能技术来清理和分离档案录音中的声音。这首歌曲深受歌迷和评论家的欢迎;自周五发布以来;。

;

;但杰克逊透露，他录制的档案片段中可能会有更多音乐在剪辑《归来》时，他拍摄了有关披头士乐队同名专辑的八小时纪录片。

;

;导演在制作《归来》时筛选了 60 小时的镜头和 150 小时的音频。

;

;导演在制作《归来》时筛选了 60 小时的镜头和 150 小时的音频。 >;

;

;;相关：;;分享你对披头士乐队最后一首歌曲《Now and Then》的看法;

;
;

;“我们可以观看《Get Back》的表演，单独约翰和乔治，然后让保罗和林戈添加合唱或和声，”《指环王》导演 ;告诉《星期日泰晤士报》;。 “你可能最终会创作出一首不错的歌曲，但我还没有与保罗讨论过这一点。

;

;“这是粉丝的东西，但肯定是可以想象的。”

;

;Now and Then 被收录在列侬的遗孀小野洋子送给三名幸存的披头士乐队的一盘标有“献给保罗”的录音带，当时他们正在进行一个回顾性项目。

;

;当时乐队成员试图完成列侬的演示，但认为不适合发布。杰克逊告诉《星期日泰晤士报》，直到 2022 年 7 月，保罗·麦卡特尼才联系他，请求他帮助制作新版本。

;

;名为 Mal（机器音频学习）的音频软件允许列侬发声与演示分开。随后，麦卡特尼和林戈·斯塔尔的新表演以及乔治·哈里森在 90 年代搁置的录音中的吉他部分对这首曲目进行了重建。 ”杰克逊告诉《星期日泰晤士报》。 “在当今世界的现状下，我们需要披头士乐队再次出现，就好像飞碟已经着陆，他们已经起飞，为我们提供最后一首歌曲来让我们振作起来。”

;

;披头士乐队上周发布了;制作视频;，深入探讨了《Now》的制作进而。麦卡特尼在视频中表达了他对将列侬的小样制作成完整歌曲的疑虑，这是出于对已故歌曲作者未完成作品的尊重。

;

;“这是我们不应该做的事情吗？”麦卡特尼说。 “每次我这样想时，我都会想，等一下，假设我有机会问约翰，‘嘿约翰，你想让我们完成你的最后一首歌吗？’我告诉你，我知道答案会是，“是的！””

; Mon, 06 Nov 2023 07:52:02 +0800 Countries agree key measures to fund most vulnerable to climate breakdownhttps://www.theguardian.com/environment/2023/nov/05/countries-agree-key-measures-to-fund-most-vulnerable-to-climate-breakdown
;;2023-11-05T18:27:12Z;
;
;;2009 年，印度布巴内斯瓦尔郊区，一名村民走过干涸的土地。
;

;各国已商定采取关键措施，向世界上最脆弱的人群提供资金，以修复气候崩溃造成的损失。

;

;富裕国家和贫穷国家的政府在经过一段时间的研究后，制定了新的“损失和损害”基金的蓝图。 ;紧张的两天会议< /a>; 在阿布扎比的联合国指导下于周六深夜结束。

;

;损失和损害基金将首先由世界银行管理，并将利用资金来源;包括发展中大国;以及美国、欧盟和英国。该基金的拨款金额尚未设定明确目标，但受气候危机影响最严重的国家希望在几年内达到数千亿美元。

;

;蓝图必须得到正式通过;第 28 届联合国气候峰会; 本月底在迪拜举行，但根据联合国气候变化框架公约成立的过渡委员会本周末达成的协议意味着这种情况是有可能发生的。

;

;Avinash Persaud，气候专家巴巴多斯和拉丁美洲和加勒比过渡委员会特使表示：“这是一个具有挑战性但至关重要的结果。我们现在首次有了一项工具，可以运作一个国际基金，为极端天气或缓发事件后的重建、恢复和搬迁提供赠款融资。这是向前迈出的重要一步，将为其他气候行动带来积极动力。”

;

;发展中国家做出了重要让步，例如同意该基金可由世界银行临时管理。发达国家还同意暗示它们应该成为该基金的主要捐助者的措辞，因为它们将被“敦促”捐款，而其他国家将被“鼓励”这样做。

;

;然而，活动人士表示，该协议不足以保证脆弱国家所需的资金，;到本十年末，每年可能达到数万亿美元;。国际气候行动网络全球政治战略负责人哈吉特·辛格表示：“对于气候正义来说，这是一个阴沉的日子，因为富裕国家背弃了弱势社区。 [This] falls short of providing vulnerable communities with adequate assurance that their financial needs for coping with climate impacts and rebuilding their lives will be met.”

;

;Loss and damage, which means the ;rescue and rehabilitation of communities; stricken by climate disaster, has been one of the most vexed issues at global climate talks for more than a decade. Poorer countries, with tiny carbon footprints, have done the least to cause the climate crisis but are bearing the brunt of its impacts.

;

;In a breakthrough last November, the Cop27 summit in Egypt ;agreed to a loss and damage fund being set up;. But four meetings of the transitional committee, charged with designing the fund, between March and October broke down in rancour as countries wrangled over who should bear most responsibility for paying in, which countries should benefit, and how the fund should be governed.

;

;Two days of intense negotiations again looked ready to break down on Saturday when the co-chairs late in the evening presented squabbling parties with a “take it or leave it” text. This “urged” developed countries to contribute to the fund and “encouraged” developing countries to do the same.

;

;Some campaigners were unhappy that developed countries were not being more strongly confronted with their past greenhouse gas emissions. Singh said: “The reluctance of wealthy nations to fulfil their financial responsibilities, in spite of historical obligations, has starkly revealed their true intentions and their indifference to the plight of the developing world.”

;

;A US state department official said: “No single government, or subset of governments, has enough resources to meet the funding needs of particularly vulnerable nations at the scale that is required. That's why we made clear throughout these negotiations how crucial it is for this fund to be able to receive financial input from the widest range of sources, including innovative ones like carbon markets, international pricing mechanisms, and others that can serve to complement grants and concessional loans from public and private sources.”

;

;The resolution represents an important diplomatic success for the UAE presidency of Cop28, which has ;come under heavy criticism; as Sultan Al Jaber, who will lead Cop28, is also head of the country's oil company, Adnoc.

;

;Al Jaber said: “This clear and strong recommendation to operationalise the loss and damage fund and funding arrangements paves the way for agreement at Cop28. Billions of people, lives and livelihoods who are vulnerable to the effects of climate change depend upon the adoption of this recommended approach at Cop28.”

;
;

;;Related: ;;Thirty years of climate summits: where have they got us? ;

;
;

;Large oil and gas producers such as UAE and Saudi Arabia should become donors to the loss and damage fund, ;many argue;. They are currently exempt as they are still classed as developing countries under the 1992 UN framework convention on climate change, the parent treaty to the ;2015 Paris agreement;.

;

;UAE has not said whether it will pay into the fund, but the Guardian understands that positive discussions are taking place.

;

;It is unclear whether campaigners will seek to reopen negotiations over the fund at Cop28. One insider told the Guardian that any party that tried to do so would face attacks from others, who regard this as the best compromise available and want to move on to other substantive issues at the summit.

;

;Several other pressing issues could also derail Cop28. 80多个国家希望达成逐步淘汰化石燃料的协议，但这遭到许多石油和天然气生产商的强烈反对。 A process known as the “global stocktake”, by which progress will be assessed on meeting the Paris agreement goal of limiting global temperature rises to 1.5C above pre-industrial level, will also be contentious, as large economies will have to face up to the inadequacy of their current efforts at emissions reduction.

; Mon, 06 Nov 2023 02:52:01 +0800 Ordeal of ‘Britain’s loneliest sheep’ continues as activists accused of intimidating farm staffhttps://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2023/nov/05/ordeal-of-britains-loneliest-sheep-continues-as-activists-accused-of-intimidating-farm-staff

;

;Police have been called to a farm in Scotland where “Britain's loneliest sheep” was due to be taken following her rescue from the foot of a cliff, after animal rights activists were accused of intimidating staff.

;

;The volunteer group Animal Rising took part in a peaceful protest outside Dalscone Farm Fun over the expected arrival of ;Fiona, who was rescued by a group of farmers; on Saturday after two years stuck at the foot of a cliff.

;

;The activists had been working on rescuing the sheep, who had grown a thick woolly fleece while living as an emigre on a beach, but they claim rival rescuers had gone behind their back to winch her up the cliff.

;

;The rescuers intended for her to be moved to the farm park, which is closed for the winter, where she would spend five months being rehabilitated before the farm opens to the public again in the spring, they said.

;

;She is being kept in a secret location until farmers feel it is safe to move her, after what they described as a “scary” and “intimidating” visit from activists, during which police were called.

;

;In a video posted on social media, the farm manager, Ben Best, said: “For the time being, Fiona's whereabouts is going to be kept secret.只有我们几个人知道她在哪里。这真是太遗憾了，因为她需要进来，她需要安定下来，她需要安全，而这些自称符合她最大利益的人实际上却不是。 She's coming to a five-star home and they're not allowing that to happen.

;

;“We have nothing to hide;我们的动物记录是无可挑剔的。我们只对我们的动物做正确的事。这对我们来说非常重要。 That comes above everything else,” he said.

;

;Animal Rising said its intentions were peaceful and it apologised to the staff and family at Dalscone Farm for the “stressful” situation, but said it were concerned that a “petting zoo” visited by the public would not be the best home for Fiona, who spent two years alone after becoming separated from her flock.

;

;She was spotted in October by a kayaker on a shingle beach on a stretch of steep, rocky coastline at Cromarty Firth, who remembered having seen her two years earlier.

; ;

;Before the rescue, members of Animal Rising had spent three days scaling the cliff to build trust with Fiona, whom they called Sheepy, in partnership with the landowner.

;

;They had an agreement, they said, to rescue the animal and take her to an animal sanctuary near Glasgow. However, on Saturday morning, when the group had left to fetch supplies, the owner broke the agreement by bringing in some farmers “who covertly smuggled Sheepy out”, they said.

;

;Robert Gordon, a spokesperson for the group, said the activists wanted to talk to the rescuers and Dalscone Farm to find a compromise.

;

;He said: “We're inviting the owners to come out and speak to us if they want to, but obviously there's no pressure if they are genuinely feeling intimidated.”

;

;Gordon said they were happy for the rescuers to take the credit for bringing Fiona to safety: “All we want is for her to be in a sanctuary, not to be made a spectacle of in a petting zoo.”

;

;Police Scotland said officers attended the scene on Sunday morning but that there were “no issues”.

;Oliver Dowden, the deputy prime minister, has denied that rape allegations against a Conservative MP were “covered up” during his time running the party's headquarters.

;

;The former party chair said the Conservatives had a “zero tolerance” approach to sexual misconduct after claims it had failed in its responsibilities towards alleged victims of a “serial rapist” MP.

;

;In a round of broadcast interviews, Dowden, who stepped down from the role in June 2022, urged any individuals with concerns about the MP, who has not been named for legal reasons, to go straight to the police.

;

;It follows reports in the Mail on Sunday that allegations of multiple sexual offences, including rape, had been made against the Conservative MP but were not dealt with properly by the party, allowing the politician to continue offending after the alarm was raised.

;

;The former Tory chairman Jake Berry, who was in post from September to October 2022, sent a letter to th epolice in which he revealed that a number of allegations about an MP had been made known to the party, but only limited action had been taken.

;“It is very difficult for me to comment specifically on this for two reasons. First of all, the individual isn't named and secondly, it may be the case that there are criminal investigations ongoing,” Dowden told the BBC's Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg programme.

;“But what I can say is that every single allegation is taken exceptionally seriously. We had an independent investigation process into it and indeed if anyone has concerns, they should be taken to the police and I would urge people to take them to the police.”

;

;He added: “I don't recognise in any form the idea that we covered up, and I can assure you, categorically, it was not the case that when I was chairman of the Conservative party, I covered up any allegations.”

;

;Dowden later told Sky News the Tory party had “zero tolerance” for sexual misconduct, adding: “We have an independent complaints mechanism and that investigates any allegations.”

;The ;Mail on Sunday; reported that Berry wrote to the police after he discovered that the Conservative party had paid for one of the alleged victims to receive treatment at a private hospital.

;The deputy prime minister later told GB News he “can't say for certain” that the party did not pay the alleged victim's hospital bills.

;Asked about the issue on Times Radio, Dowden added: “I'm not denying that it could be the case that those payments were made, but it's not something that I authorised or part of as chairman of the Conservative party.”

;Sri Lanka cricketers arrived at training for their game against Bangladesh in face masks, while players with asthma from either team stayed indoors amid poor air quality in smog-shrouded Delhi.

;

;Both teams had already cancelled one practice session in the build up to Monday's group-stage match between eliminated Bangladesh and seventh-placed Sri Lanka, who have only the slimmest of chances of reaching the last four.

;
;

;;Related: ;;Brittle Bairstow's duck sums up toxic fever dream of England's World Cup | Barney Ronay;

;
;

;Air quality remains the main talking point before the game at Arun Jaitley Stadium in New Delhi with the local air quality index (AQI) an alarming 460 on Sunday. An AQI of 0-50 is considered good while anything between 400-500 affects healthy people and is considered a danger to those with existing diseases.

;

;The Sri Lanka head coach, Chandika Hathurusinghe, said his team were trying to minimise exposing their players to such conditions ahead of the match. “Our doctor is keeping a close eye on the players,” he told reporters on Sunday.

;

;“Some of the players didn't turn up for practice as they are asthmatic, so they stayed indoors,” Hathurusinghe added. “即使是练习，我们也非常有意识。我们训练我们必须训练的东西，然后回到更衣室。 They don't spend time outdoors unless they're bowling or batting.”

; ;

;The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) has banned the use of fireworks in post-match celebrations after Monday's match, the last in Delhi. The International Cricket Council (ICC) said it was monitoring the situation, while local schools will remain closed until 10 November due to the poor air quality in the region.

;

;“It's not ideal, but we have no choice.我们必须在我们面前的条件下比赛，”哈图鲁辛赫补充道。 “团队的选择不会取决于空气质量。这取决于条件、对手和我们的实力。” The head coach added he was not “a qualified person” to judge whether Delhi was a suitable venue at this time of year.

;

;The Sri Lanka captain, Kusal Mendis, later dismissed media reports claiming that the 1996 champions had requested the ICC to shift the match to another venue. “We didn't make a request to change ... we just asked them what's the plan,” Mendis told reporters.

;

;“I think they have installed some equipment here, and they've got specialists to check [the air quality], Mendis added. “他们已经通知我们他们计划继续进行。 So we will do exactly what the ICC actually tells us to do.”

; Sun, 05 Nov 2023 23:22:01 +0800 Zelenskiy denies Ukrainian general’s claim war is at stalematehttps://www.theguardian.com/world/2023/nov/05/zelenskiy-denies-ukrainian-generals-claim-war-is-at-stalemate
;;2023-11-05T14:38:18Z;
;
;;A member of a Ukrainian artillery unit carries ammunition
;

;Volodymyr Zelenskiy has denied a suggestion from the Ukrainian military's commander-in-chief that the war with Russia has ;reached a stalemate;, and a senior spokesperson for his administration has rebuked the general in question and accused him of making “the aggressor's job easier”.

;

;Gen Valerii Zaluzhnyi had offered his blunt assessment of the current situation in an interview published this week. “Just like in the first world war, we have reached the level of technology that puts us into a stalemate,” ;he told the Economist;, adding: “There will most likely be no deep and beautiful breakthrough.”

;

;Zaluzhnyi said the war had entered a phase of attritional fighting in which neither side would make much progress unless there was a technological breakthrough. He also suggested that Russia was slowly getting the upper hand thanks to its superior numbers.

;

;The general said he had underestimated Vladimir Putin's willingness to sacrifice his own soldiers, saying at least 150,000 had been killed so far. “说实话，[俄罗斯]是一个封建国家，最便宜的资源就是人命。 And for us … the most expensive thing we have is our people,” Zaluzhnyi said.

;

;Prolonged fighting had put Ukraine at a disadvantage, he admitted. “This will benefit Russia, allowing it to rebuild its military power, eventually threatening Ukraine's armed forces and the state itself.”

;

;On Saturday, Zelenskiy denied that the war was at a stalemate and said more work with allies was needed to strengthen air defences.

;

;“Today time has passed and people are tired, but this is not a stalemate,” he said during a news conference with the visiting European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen. “俄罗斯控制着天空。 We care about our military.”

;

;Zelenskiy acknowledged there had been difficulties in the war, which is now in its 21st month, and he conceded that Kyiv had yet to achieve any major successes in its counteroffensive.

;

;But he said Ukrainian troops had no alternative but to keep fighting and needed more support from western allies, especially with air defences.

;

;Ukrainian forces have made slow progress through vast Russian minefields in a counteroffensive that began in the east and south in early June, but Russia has hit back hard in the east.

;

;Zelenskiy's aide Ihor Zhovkva upbraided Zaluzhnyi for his comments, warning that they could be used to Russia's advantage.

;

;“If I were the military, probably the last thing I would do is to comment to the press and the public on what is happening at the front, what may happen at the front, and possible options,” he said in televised remarks reported by the Kyiv Independent.

;

;“Because then we make the aggressor's job easier. I am sure that everything has been read very carefully and noted, and conclusions have been drawn.”

;

;Zhovkva added: “If we can achieve success this way, then perhaps this is a very deep strategic plan. But it seems very strange to me.”

;

;The Kremlin has also taken issue with Zaluzhnyi's assessment of the state of the conflict. Asked by reporters on Thursday whether Zaluzhnyi was right that the conflict was moving towards an impasse, the Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said: “No, it has not reached a stalemate.”

;

;He said it was “absurd” for Kyiv to talk about a possible Ukrainian victory on the battlefield. “The sooner the Kyiv regime understands this for itself, the sooner some prospects will open up,” Peskov added.

;

;On Friday, Zelenskiy announced that he had put a new commander in charge of Ukraine's special forces. He gave no explanation for the appointment.

;

;Zelenskiy said in his nightly video address that Col Serhiy Lupanchuk would now head the forces, describing him as “an experienced officer, combat officer and the right man in command”.

;

;The president said Lupanchuk's predecessor, Maj Gen Viktor Horenko, who had led the forces from July 2022, would continue to carry out “special tasks” within the defence ministry's intelligence directorate.
;
; Horenko said in an interview that he had been told nothing. “我个人并不知道原因。 Let me just say that I learned of this from the media,” he told the Ukrainska Pravda news site.
;
; Ukraine's special forces are believed to be behind the most sophisticated operations its military has conducted in areas under Russian control, in particular in Crimea, which was annexed by Moscow in 2014, eight years before Moscow's full land invasion.

;

;Recent examples include a strike in September on the headquarters of Russia's Black Sea Fleet command in Sevastopol, and attacks on a patrol ship and a submarine stationed in the peninsula.

;

;;Reuters contributed to this report.;

;Hebert Amorim was eight when he got his first taste of ;funk carioca; (Rio funk): ;a pirate CD; by Mr Catra, a favela MC famed for his ferociously explicit verses about gangs, guns and sex.

;“My mum caught me listening to it and went mental,” said the 30-year-old visual artist from Senador Camará, a hardscrabble corner of west Rio de Janeiro where police fear to tread.

;

;Amorim's compositions are among 900 pieces in a new exhibition at Rio's Museum of Art (MAR) celebrating the funk movement and its role in Brazilian society, culture and politics. ;More than three decades after the birth of ;funk carioca; – which boasts more than half a dozen subgenres and lyrics that can be smutty, frivolous, politically aware or downright illegal in their glorification of gangland life – debate still rages over its roots.有人称其为迈阿密贝斯和黑帮说唱的南美融合。 Others believe it derives from an Afro-Brazilian rhythm called ; Maculelê;.

;Marcelo Campos, MAR's curator-in-chief, said ;the show; was a deliberate rebuttal to art snobs who believed museums should only display the “high culture” of Brazil's predominantly white elites and considered funk “the stuff of outlaws”.

;

;“It's an exhibition that seeks to completely turn the page on the idea of funk being a taboo,” Campos said during a tour of the show's two halls – one focusing on Rio's black history and another on the favela funk movement itself. “Our message is that [funk] is absolutely top-notch culture.”

;

;For Amorim, the surprise was not that an important museum was hosting a show about funk, but that this had not happened before. “事实上，这件事早就该发生了。 Funk is one of the greatest – if not ;the; greatest – legacy of our times,” the artist said, as he sat on his roof surveying the area that inspires his work.

; ;

;The MAR exhibition places funk in a century-long tradition of black culture, resistance and empowerment stretching back to music legends such as the flautist and saxophonist ;Pixinguinha;, early last century. The precursors of today's ;favela funk ;;;bailes;; (dances) began in the 1970s, as music lovers packed suburban nightclubs to groove to the sound of James Brown and Kool & the Gang.

;

;Those soul and funk dances later moved inside the favelas – today home to 20% of Rio's 6.6 million inhabitants – and became a deafening cultural and social phenomenon as Amorim grew up in the 1990s and 2000s. Today, Rio's biggest ;bailes; – many named after foreign countries or cities including Egypt, the Netherlands, Moscow and London – attract tens of thousands of revellers and are a key part of the local economy.

;

;“You can forget about sleeping when a funk party's happening. It's like the music's playing inside your home,” Amorim said of the ear-splitting all-night raves that take place near his childhood home.

;

;Amorim called funk a way of chronicling and celebrating the hard-knock realities of Rio's favelas, control of which authorities have largely surrendered to the heavily armed drug factions. “芬克是讲述生活中赤裸裸的真相。放克是我们生活的现实，”他说。 “It's the thing everyone sees but nobody wants to discuss.”

;

;Amorim, whose artistic name is ;Artedeft;, hoped to achieve something similar with his collages, which mix scenes of favela life with “samples” from painters including Van Gogh, Edvard Munch and Paul Gauguin. “I talk about a Rio that's right in front of me – if you look out at the street you'll see my art, whichever way you look,” said the artist, who didn't visit an art museum until seeing a Salvador Dalí retrospective when he was 21.

; ;

;Another artist in the show, ;Juan Calvet;, 25, said he cried after receiving MAR's invitation.三年前他才参观了他的第一个博物馆。 “这是一次非常强大的经历，你知道吗？ Coming to the museum and seeing yourself in so many different ways,” Calvet said.

;

;Museumgoers from the favelas voiced similar sentiments as they snapped selfies with funk-inspired sculptures and canvases that spoke to their lives.

;

;“I saw myself,” said Andreia Sampaio da Silva, a fortysomething-year-old trans woman, reminiscing about the ;bailes de corredor; (“corridor dances”) she frequented in her youth, where rival funk collectives held dance-offs that often turned violent.

;

;Campos thought deep-rooted intolerance and elitism explained why museums had previously shunned funk and the favelas.

;

;“Funk suffers the same prejudice samba suffered.桑巴舞也被认为是亡命之徒的玩意儿。人们被逮捕了。演出停播。 Lyrics banned,” said the curator, who wanted MAR to challenge such preconceptions with exhibitions reflecting contemporary society.

;

;“There's no point in continuing to think – as people have for so long – that the best thing to do here is educate society by exhibiting a Mona Lisa. That no longer cuts it.”
